name: Coal loading silo;  Manufacture; For railcar loading of coal, surface mine
description:
This process is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  To access the library and the original dataset:
1) Navigate to the NETL LCA home page (http://www.netl.doe.gov/lca)
2) Then navigate to the “Unit Process Library” 
3) From the library, the unit process of interest can be found either through the "Complete Listing of the Unit Process Library link" or through the link to the "Unit Process Database" spreadsheet
4) For each process, a Data Sheet (DS) and Data File (DF) are available

BRIEF DESCRIPTION
This parameterized unit process is based on specifications for a Powder River Coal Corp, 12,000-ton coal silo, used for railcar loading of Poweder River Basin (PRB) sub-bituminous coal at the mine site. Assumes silo constructed of steel and concrete, with negligible amounts of other materials.

GOAL AND SCOPE
The scope of this unit process covers the materials required for the construction of a single, 12,000–ton, steel-and-concrete, coal-loading silo, used to load PRB subbituminous coal into railcars. The unit process is based on the reference flow of 1 piece of coal-loading silo under Life Cycle (LC) Stage #1, as described in the associated documentation (referenced below). The coal-loading silo is assumed to be constructed of steel plate and concrete; other materials are assumed to be negligible. This coal-loading silo construction unit process, along with other construction unit processes for PRB sub-bituminous coal preparation equipment, is combined in a separate assembly process for PRB sub-bituminous coal processing, Coal mine equipment assembly; Production mix; Surface coal mine, Powder river basin, U.S. This assembly unit process quantifies the fraction of each piece of equipment needed under LC Stage #1 to produce 1 kg of PRB sub-bituminous coal ready for transport (LC Stage #2) to the energy conversion facility (LC Stage #3). Surface coal mine operations are modeled in DS_Stage1_O_CoalMine_PRB_2010.01.xls, which quantifies the extraction and preparation of 1 kg of coal.

BOUNDARY AND DESCRIPTION
Construction of the coal-loading silo is based on available data for the construction of a PRB coal-loading silo. Heights for PRB coal loading silos range between 220 and 240 feet tall, while the width appears to be a third of the height (PRC 2009). It is assumed that the thickness of the walls and ceiling is two feet, while the base of the structure is eight feet thick. The coal-loading silo is used to load coal into individual rail cars at the PRB sub-bituminous coal mine site.

Emissions related to the physical assembly of the loading silo (e.g., emitted when putting together the components of the silo, including transport of the components) are not considered in this study. Upstream emission from the production of raw materials used in the construction of the loading silo (e.g., steel plate) are calculated outside the boundary of this process, based on proprietary profiles available within the GaBi model. The loading silo constructed in this unit process is incorporated into the construction assembly process for LC Stage #1. 

The weight of the silo was not readily available. Based on the dimensions of the loading silo discussed above, weights were calculated. The silo is assumed to be 15% steel plate, with the remaining 85 percent assumed to be concrete. The shape of the silo is a cylinder with a hole at the bottom for the trains to pull under, to facilitate loading into the railcars. Additional details regarding input and output flows, including calculation methods, are contained in the associated documentation as referenced below.

This process contains one or more surrogate product flows as replacements for proprietary product flows used in the NETL Unit Process Library.  All surrogate flow were taken from the U.S. Life Cycle Inventory Database; a list of surrogate flows used in this process is provided below:
1) Portland cement, at plant: This flow is a proxy for Ready Mixed Concrete.  This process calculates the required mass of Portland Cement as a fraction of the required mass of Ready Mixed Concrete to construct one coal loading silo.  The default parameter setting assumes that Portland Cement comprises 14.1% (by mass) of Ready Mixed Concrete (NIST 2009); however, this parameter may be modified by the user.  This process does not consider other material and energy inputs for producing Ready Mixed Concrete.


CITATION AND ASSOCIATED DOCUMENTATION
This document should be cited as: 
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2015. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Coal loading silo;  Manufacture; For railcar loading of coal, surface mine. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: September 2015 (Version 01). Retrieved on [DATE] from [URL for this dataset].

This dataset is part of the NETL Unit Process Library.  The Library offers additional information concerning this dataset in the form of a Detailed Spreadsheet  Documentation (DS) file and a Process Documentation File (DF).  The DS file  is an Excel file that contains all of the parameters, inputs, and outputs for a given system as well as background data, calculations and quality scores.  The DF file is a PDF document that contains major assumptions and data sources that are the basis for each unit process.  The NETL Unit Process Library is located on the NETL website (netl.doe.gov) under Research / Energy Analysis / Energy Trends and Issues / Life Cycle Analysis / Unit Process Library.

This dataset was converted directly from the DS with additional supporting information provided by the DF.  Full citations for the DS and DF are given below.

DS File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2010. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Coal-Loading Silo, 12,000 Tons, Powder River Basin (PRB), Construction. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: February 2010 (version 01). Retrieved on 06/30/2014 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DS_Stage1_C_Coal_Loading_Silo_PRB_2010-01.xls

DF File
National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL). 2010. NETL Life Cycle Inventory Data – Unit Process: Coal-Loading Silo, 12,000 Tons, Powder River Basin (PRB), Construction. U.S. Department of Energy, National Energy Technology Laboratory. Last Updated: February 2010 (version 01). Retrieved on 06/30/2014 from: http://www.netl.doe.gov/File%20Library/Research/Energy%20Analysis/Life%20Cycle%20Analysis/UP_Library/DF_Stage1_C_Coal_Loading_Silo_PRB_2010-01.pdf

category.name: Bit. Coal and Lignite Surface Mining

processDocumentation.timeDescription: This data set is representative of best available public data from 01/01/2006 to 12/31/2006 and is not subject to limited usability within sub-time spans (e.g. summer, winter).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The scope of this unit process covers the materials required for the construction of a single, 12,000–ton, steel-and-concrete, coal-loading silo, used to load Powder River Basin subbituminous coal into railcars. Construction of the coal-loading silo is based on available data for the construction of a PRB coal-loading silo (PRC 2009). The coal-loading silo is used to load coal into individual rail cars at the PRB sub-bituminous coal mine site.
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription: All elementary and technosphere flows are calculated on a functional unit basis. Calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful work are done using lower heating values (LHV) and calculations involving combustion primarily to generate useful heat are done using higher heating values (HHV). Unless explicitly stated in the associated reference documents applicable calculations assumed standard atmospheric temperature and pressure (SATP).
processDocumentation.restrictionsDescription:

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: This is a gate-to-gate manufacturing process and can be used for any type of LCA study.
